section.title: Complex Numbers

introduction.p: All the mathematical work you have done so far has involved using real numbers. In this section, we will work with a new set of numbers called the complex numberscomplex numbers; it should be noted that the real numbers are actually a specific case of the complex numbers.

subsection.title: Motivation
subsection.p:
Let's start by providing some background as to where complex numbers arise from. Suppose that we want to solve for the x-intercepts of f(x) = x^2 -2x + 2. We can use the quadratic formula to obtain the x-intercepts, and when doing so, we obtain the following expression: x = \frac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(-2)^2-4(1)(2)}}{2(1)} = \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{-4}}{2}.
Notice that \sqrt{-4} is not a real number because there are no real numbers whose square is negative. In fact, the square of any real number is either positive or zero. As a result, f(x) = x^2 -2x + 2 has no real x-intercepts. This can be also be verified graphically since the graph of f(x) = x^2 - 2x + 2 never crosses the x-axis. (INSERT GRAPH)

section.subsection:
Imaginary Numbers
Even though the square root of a negative number is not a real number, we can still work with it by defining a new set of numbers, i.e. the complex numbers. Before we do any work with complex numbers, let's define the imaginary unitimaginary unit.
Imaginary Unit
The imaginary unit i is defined as i = \sqrt{-1} or i^2 = -1.
It is important to be aware that the letter i is used to represent a constant, not a variable! With the number i, we can now define imaginary numbersimaginary numbers.
Imaginary Numbers
Let a > 0 be a real number. Then, \sqrt{-a} = \sqrt{a}\sqrt{-1} = \sqrt{a}i.
Let's refer back to the example introduced earlier in this section. The value \sqrt{-4} can be expressed as follows:
\sqrt{-4} \amp= \sqrt{4(-1)} \amp= \sqrt{4}\sqrt{-1} \amp = sqrt{4}i \amp = 2i .
Here are more examples of imaginary numbers 5i, \frac{2}{3}i, -24i, and \sqrt{15}i.

Complex Numbers Recall that when we are solving for the x-intercepts of f(x) = x^2 -2x + 2, we obtained the following values for x with the quadratic formula:
x = \frac{2\pm \sqrt{-4}}{2}.
Using our new established knowledge of imaginary numbers, we find that x = \frac{2\pm 2i}{2} which implies that x = 1 + i or 1 - i. These x-values are examples of complex numberscomplex numbers.
Complex Numbers
A complex number can be written in the form
z = a + bi
where a and b are real numbers. Here, a is called the real part and b is called the imaginary part.
From this definition, we can observe that all real numbers are actually complex numbers with imaginary part equal to 0. Moreover, imaginary numbers are actually complex numbers with real part equal to 0; these numbers are called pure imaginary numbers.
The reader shoudl note that the real and imaginary parts of a complex number can never be combined. Hence, two complex numbers are equal if and only if their real parts equal and their imaginary parts are equal.
Equality of Complex Numbers
Two complex numbers z = a+bi and w = c+di are equal if and only if a = c and b = d.

Arithmetic of Complex Numbers Like real numbers, we can use the following arithmetic operations with complex numbers: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
Sum and Difference of Complex Numbers
Consider two complex number z = a+bi and w = c+di. Then their sum is given by z+w = (a+bi) + (c+di) = (a+c) + (b+d)i, and their difference is given by z-w = (a+bi) - (c+di) = (a-c) + (b-d)i.
Compute (4+5i) + (8-6i) and (2-3i) - (5+2i).
(4+5i) + (8-6i) \amp= (4+8) + (5-6)i \amp= 12 + (-1)i \amp= 12 - i
and
(2-3i) - (5+2i) \amp= (2-5) - (-3+2)i \amp= (-3) - (-1)i \amp= -3 + i.
When taking the product of two complex numbers, you should always remember that i^2 = -1. The product of two pure imaginary numbers is very nice and straightfoward to do.
Product of Pure Imaginary Numbers
Consider two pure imaginary numbers z = ai and w = bi. Then their product is given by zw = (ai)(bi) = (ab)i^2 = -ab.
Finding the product of two complex is slightly different since we need to use the distributive property.
Product of Complex Numbers
Consider two complex numbers z = a+bi and w = c+di. Then their product is given by zw = (a+bi)(c+di) = (ac - bd) + (ad + bc)i.
Compute (3i)(4i) and (2+3i)(-3-2i).
(3i)(4i) \amp= (3\cdot 4)i^2 \amp= 12(-1) \amp= -12,
and
(2+3i)(-3-2i) \amp= (2(-3) - 3(-2)) + (2(-2) + 3(-3))i \amp= (-6 + 6) + (-4-9)i \amp= 0 - 13i \amp= -13i.
WARNING: The following property is true with real numbers, but it fails with complex numbers: \sqrt{ab} = \sqrt{a}\sqrt{b}. Here is a counter-example: let a = b = -2. Then, \sqrt{ab} = \sqrt{(-2)(-2)} = \sqrt{4} = 2, but \sqrt{a}\sqrt{b} \amp= \sqrt{-2}\sqrt{-2} \amp= (\sqrt{2}i)(\sqrt{2}i) \amp= (\sqrt{2})^2i^2 \amp = 2(-1) = -2. Hence, \sqrt{ab} \neq \sqrt{a}\sqrt{b} (especially when a, b are both negative).
Finding the quotient of two complex numbers requires us to use the technique of rationalizing the denominator. We will consider two different types of quotients: division by a pure imaginary number and division by a complex number.
Division by a Pure Imaginary Number
Consider a complex number z = a+bi and a pure imaginary number w = ci. Then, \frac{z}{w} = \frac{a+bi}{ci} = \frac{a+bi}{ci}\cdot \frac{i}{i} = \frac{(a+bi)i}{ci^2} = \frac{-b + ai}{-c} = \frac{b - ai}{c}.
When dividing by a complex number, we rationalize the denonimator by multiplying by the complex conjugate.
Complex Conjugate For any complex number z = a + bi, the number \bar{z} = a - bi is called the complex conjugate of z.
FACT: The product of a complex number and its conjugate is a real number. That is, z\bar{z} = (a+bi)(a-bi) = a^2 -abi + abi - b^2i^2 = a^2 - b^2(-1) = a^2 + b^2.
Quotient of two Complex Number Consider two complex numbers z = a+bi and w = c + di. Then, \frac{z}{w} = \frac{a+bi}{c+di} = \frac{a+bi}{c+di}\cdot \frac{c-di}{c-di] = \frac{ac+bd}{c^2+d^2} + \frac{bc-ad}{c^2+d^2}i.
Compute \frac{8+9i}{2i} and \frac{4-2i}{2+3i}.
\frac{8+9i}{2i} \amp= \frac{8+9i}{2i}\cdot\frac{i}{i}
\amp= \frac{(8+9i)i}{2i^2} \amp= \frac{8i + 9i^2}{2(-1)} \amp= \frac{8i + 9(-1)}{-2} \amp= \frac{-9+8i}{-2} \amp= \frac{9-8i}{2},
and
\frac{4-2i}{2+3i} \amp= \frac{4-2i}{2+3i}\cdot \frac{2-3i}{2-3i}
\amp= \frac{(4-2i)(2+3i)}{(2)^2 + (3)^2} \amp= \frac{(4(2)-(-2)(3)) + (4(3)+(-2)(2))i}{13} \amp= \frac{(8+6)+(12-4)i}{13} \amp= \frac{14+8i}{13}.

Graphing Compex Numbers Like real numbers, we can actually graph complex numbers. To plot a complex number, we will utilize a plane called the complex planecomplex plane. The complex plane has two axes; the horizontal axis (real axis) will be used to plot the real part, and the vertical axis (imaginary axis) will be used to plot the imaginary part. The point where the real and imaginary axes cross is called the origin, and it is denoted by (0,0).
Plotting a Complex Number To plot a complex number z = a + bi, we move a units in the horizontal direction and then we move b units in the vertical direction.
Plot the complex numbers 2+4i, -2+6i, and -3-i in the complex plane.
To plot 2+4i, we move 2 units to the right from the origin, and then we move 3 units up. To plot -2+6i, we move 2 units to the left from the origin, and then we move 6 units up. To plot -3-i, we move 3 units to the left from the origin, and then we move 1 unit down.
INCLUDE FIGURES!!
REMARK: Whenever we plot a complex number z = a + bi, we sometimes use the notation (a,b) to denote a point in the complex plane. In this context, (a,b) represents a single complex number whose real part is a and imaginary part is b.
We can actually measure the distance a point in the complex plane is from the origin using the Pythagorean theorem. This distance is called the modulusmodulus.
Modulus of a Complex Number The modulus of a complex number z = a + bi is given by |z| = \sqrt{a^2+b^2} Observe that |z| \geq 0.
Compute the modulus of z = 3 + 4i and w = -1 + i. |z| = \sqrt{3^2 + 4^2} = \sqrt{25} = 5 and |w| = \sqrt{(-1)^2 + 1^2} = \sqrt{1 + 1} = \sqrt{2}
